0.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathaniel has been conversing. They mock his inferior intellect, criticizing his pronunciation and saying that they abhor 'such rackers of orthography' . Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the learned men that the King has asked him to prepare 'some delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antick or firework'  to entertain the Princess and her party. He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for their help in planning this entertainment, and Holofernes suggests that they present a show of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, with Holofernes saying that he will play three of the roles himself. They then go off to plan their show.

2.text:
Holofernes and Nathaniel were discussing Don Quixote, with whom Nathaniel had recently conversed. They mocked his intellect, criticized his pronunciation, saying they detested 'that Orthography nonsenseness'.

Don Quixote, Mosca and Sancho Panza entered, and Don Quixote told the scholars that the king had asked him to prepare a 'charming performance, show, procession, acrobatics or fireworks' to entertain the princess and her guests.

He asked Holofernes and Nathaniel if they could help him plan the entertainment, and Holofernes suggested they present a show of nine worthies. 

They discussed who would play the role of the sage, with Holofernes saying he would play the triangle. They then left to plan the performance.

4.text:
Don Quixote and Sancho Panza entered, and Don Quixote told the scholars that the king requested him to prepare a 'captivating spectacle, entertainment, parade, acrobatics, or fireworks' to entertain the princess and her guests.

He asked Holoferns and Nathaniel if they could help him plan the entertainment, and Holoferns suggested presenting the performance of the Nine Wise Men.

They discussed who would play the wise men, and Holoferns said he would play the triangle.  After that, they left to plan the performance.

6.text:
Don Quixote and Sancho Panza entered the room, Don Quixote told the scholars that the king had asked him to prepare a 'pleasant show, entertainment, procession, flying men or fireworks display' to welcome the princess and her guests.

He asked for the help of Holophernes and Nastagio to plan the entertainment, Holophernes suggested performing 'The Nine Worthies'.

They discussed who would play the wise men, Holophernes said he would play three triangles of iron. Then they left to plan the show.

8.text:
Don Quixote and Sancho Panza entered the room, and Don Quixote explained to the scholars that the king had requested him to arrange a 'joyful performance, entertainment, procession, aerial performance, or fireworks display' for the princess and her guests.

He asked for the help of Hollenfensis and Nitro to plan the entertainment, and Hollenfensis suggested a performance of 'The Nine Worthies.' 

They discussed who would play the wise men, and Hollenfensis said he would play the iron triangle. They then left to plan the performance.

10.text:
Father Dominic and Pancha Hill entered the room, Father Dominic explained to the scholars that the king had requested that he arrange for the princess and her guests a 'joyful performance, entertainment, procession, aerial performance, or fireworks display.'

He asked Hollenfens and Nittel to help him plan the entertainment, they said that Hollenfens suggested performing 'The Nine Wise Men.'

They discussed who would play the wise men, Hollenfens said he would play the Three Musketeers. Then, they left to plan the performance.

13.text:
Father Francis and Panch entered the room, Father Francis explained to the scholars that the king had requested that he arrange for the princess and her guests a 'joyful performance, entertainment, procession, aerial performance or fireworks display'.

He asked Hornsby and Nettle to help him plan the entertainment, saying that Hornsby had suggested a 'performance by nine wise men'.

They discussed who would play the wise men, Hornsby said he would play three warriors. Then, they left to plan the performance.

16.text:
Father Francis and Pancho entered the room. Father Francis explained to the scholars that the king had requested that he arrange a 'joyful performance, entertainment, procession, aerial performance, or fireworks display' for the princess and her guests.

He asked Hornsby and Niter to help him plan the entertainment, saying that Hornsby had suggested a performance of nine wise men. They discussed who would play the wise men, with Hornsby saying that he would play three warriors. Then, they left to plan the performance.

20.text: Father Francis and Panch entered the room. Father Francis ordered Scholar Wang to arrange for the princess and her guest a 'joyful performance, entertainment, procession, aerial performance or fireworks display.' He asked Hosenpfeffer and Noot to help him plan the entertainment, saying Hosenpfeffer suggested a performance of 'the Nine Worthies.' The three discussed who would perform the Worthies, with Hosenpfeffer saying he would play three knights. They eventually left to plan the performance.

25.text: Father Francis and Baron entered the room. Father Francis instructed the scholars to prepare for the princess and her guests 'a merry entertainment, a show, a procession, aerial performances, or a fireworks display.' He asked Hopaville and Nott to assist him in planning the entertainment, and pointed out that Hopaville had previously suggested a 'Nine Worthies' performance. The three men discussed who would play the Nine Worthies, with Hopaville saying he would play three of the knights. Finally, the three men left to plan the performance.

30.text: Father Francis and Baron entered the room. Father Francis instructed the scholars to prepare a celebration, entertainment, procession, aerial performance, or fire dance for the princess and her guests. He requested Hopp (a jester's nickname), not for his assistance, but for his entertainment, pointing out that Hopp had previously suggested a 'Nine Worthies' performance. The three discussed who would perform the Nine Worthies, Hopp saying he would play three knights. Finally, the three left to plan the performance.

40.text:
Francis' father and Barlow entered the room. Francis' father ordered the scholars to prepare a celebration, entertainment, procession, aerial performance, or fireworks for the princess and her guests.

He also asked Hope (the stage name of the comedian) not only to provide entertainment but to prove that Hope had previously suggested the performance of 'The Nine Worthies'.

The three of them discussed who would perform 'The Nine Worthies', Hope said he would play three of the knights.

Finally, the three of them left the room to start preparing the performance.

50.text:
Francis's father and Barul entered the room. Francis's father ordered the scholars to prepare a celebration, entertainment, procession, aerial performance, or fireworks for the princess and her guests.

He also asked Hop (the stage name of the comedian) not only to provide entertainment, but also to prove that Hop had previously suggested performing 'The Nine Wise Men'.

The three discussed who would perform 'The Nine Wise Men', Hop said he would play three knights.

Finally, the three left the room to prepare for the performance.

65.text:
Francis's father and Babur entered the room. Francis's father ordered the scholars to prepare a celebration for the princess and her guests, including performances, processions, aerial performances or fireworks.

He also requested that Hopp (a stage name of a comedian) not only provide the performance, but also prove that Hopp had previously suggested the performance of 'Nine Heroes'.

The three of them discussed who would perform 'Nine Heroes', with Hopp saying he would play three knights.

Finally, the three of them left the room to start preparing the performance.

80.text:
Francis's father and Babur entered the room. Francis's father ordered the scholars to prepare a celebration for the princess and her guests, including performances, parades, aerial performances, or fireworks.

He also requested that Hobie (Hobie being the stage name of the comedian) not only provide performances but also prove that Hobie had previously suggested a program featuring 'Nine Wise Men.'

The three of them discussed who would play 'Nine Wise Men,' with Hobie saying he would play three knights.

Finally, the three of them left the room to prepare for the performance.

100.text:
Francis's father and Babur entered the room. Francis's father ordered scholars to prepare a celebration for the princess and her guests, including performances, parades, aerial performances, or rocket performances.

He also requested that Hors (Hors is the pen name of the comedian), in addition to providing performances, arrange the script of the script previously proposed by Hors, The Nine Wise Men.

The three discussed who would perform in The Nine Wise Men, with Hors saying he would play the role of three knights.

Finally, the three left the room to prepare for the performance.

0.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the happiest and most content that spring just playing in the garden. They do not yet know that the summer will change everything. In the beginning of summer, some Italians come into town and set up a dancing pavilion in a vacant lot. They begin giving dancing lessons to children, and people start to gather and congregate around the lot. Now there is something for people to do and somewhere for them to socialize. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there is a late-night dance. Jim goes all the time, as do many girls and boys from the country. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the hired girls' and are always at the dances too.

2.text:
James and Harrington's children felt the happiest and most satisfied while playing in the garden during spring, but they didn't know how summer would change everything.

At the beginning of summer, some Italians came to the small town and set up a dance hall on an empty square. The Italians began teaching dance lessons to the children, and people started gathering around the square. Now, people had something to do and a place for socializing. Dance became the town's latest craze, with parties held every Saturday night. James always attended, and every Saturday night, he would bring many village girls and boys.

At that time, Antonia, Lena, and Tina were called 'hired girls' and always appeared at the dance.

4.text:
James and Harlington's children were the happiest and most satisfied when playing in the garden in spring, but they had no idea how summer would change everything.

At the beginning of summer, some Italians came to the town, rented a vacant square, and built a dance hall. The Italians started teaching the children how to dance, and people began to gather around the square. Now, people had a place to do things and socialize. Dancing became the latest trend in town, with dance parties held every Saturday night. James always attended, and every Saturday night, he would bring many girls and boys from the village.

At that time, Antonia, Lena, and Tina were known as 'hired girls,' and they always appeared at the dance parties.

6.text:
James and Harrington's children are the happiest and most content when playing in the garden in the spring, but they have no idea how summer will change everything.

In the beginning of summer, a few Italians came to this small town, rented an empty square, and built a dance hall. The Italians started teaching the children how to dance, and people began gathering around the square. Now, people have a place for socializing and getting things done. Dancing became the latest trend in town, with a dance party held every Saturday night. James would attend every time, and on Saturday nights, he would bring many girls and boys from the village.

At that time, Antonia, Lena, and Tina were called the 'hired girls,' and they always appeared at the dance parties.

At that time, Antonia, Lena, and Tina were known as the 'hired girls,' always appearing at the dance parties.

10.text:
James and Harlington's children were at their happiest and most content in the spring, unaware of how the summer would change everything.

As summer began, some Italians arrived in the small town, renting a plot of land to build a dance hall. The Italians started teaching the children how to dance, and people began gathering around the square. Now, they had a place for socializing and conducting business. Dancing became the latest trend in town, with a dance party held every Saturday night. James always attended, bringing many girls and boys from the surrounding villages to join in on the Saturday night dance parties.

At the time, Antonia, Lena, and Tina were known as the 'hired girls,' always appearing at the dance parties.

0.text: Elizabeth reads through Darcy's letter with a mixture of emotions. When she first reads Darcy's explanation of his conduct with Bingley and Jane, she dismisses his explanation of his concern about Jane's indifference as false, and believes he acted solely because of her family. However, when she begins reading his explanation of the dealings with Wickham, she begins to read more clearly. She soon begins to realize that she had not known anything of Wickham before the night when he told her of he and Darcy, and she wonders why she didn't realize his impropriety at speaking of such things to a stranger. As she continues to reread and think, she realizes that she had been 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believes Darcy's version of what happened. She then rereads the section about Jane and Bingley, and sees that she cannot deny the justice of his description of Jane's seeming indifference after all. After two hours of wandering in the park she returns home to be told that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to say their good-byes

2.text: When Elizabeth read Darcy's letter, her emotions were in turmoil. At first, when she read his explanation of himself and Jane, she thought his concern that she was indifferent to Jane was unfounded, and that his behavior was entirely due to her family. However, as she began to read his explanation of Wickham, she read on with increasing clarity. She soon realized that she had known nothing about Wickham until that night when he told her about his connection to Darcy, and she began to wonder why she had not noticed his inappropriateness in discussing these matters. As she continued to read and think, she realized that her previous views were 'blind, biased, partial, and absurd,' and she believed Darcy's version. Then, she re-read the parts about Jane and Bingley, and saw Darcy's seeming indifference to Jane as justice. After a two-hour walk, she returned home, only to be told that the Fitzwilliam and Darcy had already visited, and had taken their leave.

4.text: After reading Darcy's letter, Elizabeth was in a state of great turmoil. Initially, when she read Darcy's explanation about himself and Jane, she thought that his concerns about her being indifferent to Jane were unfounded, and that his behavior was entirely due to her family. However, as she continued to read Darcy's explanation about Wickham, her understanding became clearer and clearer. She soon realized that she had known nothing about Wickham until he told her about his connection to Darcy on that night, and she began to ponder why she had not noticed the inappropriateness of his behavior when discussing these matters. Continuing to read and think, she realized that her previous views were 'blind, biased, one-sided, and absurd', and she believed Darcy's version. Then, she read that part about Jane and Bingley again, and saw that Darcy's seeming indifference to Jane was actually reasonable. Two hours later, when she returned home, she found that Fitzwilliam and Darcy had already visited and left.

Soon, she realized she knew nothing about Wickham until he told her about his relationship with Darcy on that night, and she began to think about why she hadn't noticed his inappropriate behavior when discussing these matters. Continuing to read and think, she realized her initial premise was 'blind, biased, one-sided, and absurd,' and she began to believe Darcy's version. Then, she read the part about Jane and Bingley again, and seeing Darcy's behavior towards Jane seemed cold, but was actually reasonable. Two hours later, when she returned home, she found that Fitzwilliam and Darcy had already visited and left.

It wasn't until the evening, when Wickham's relationship with Mr. Darcy was revealed, that she began to reflect on why she hadn't noticed his improper behavior. Through further reading and reflection, she discovered that her initial assumptions were 'blind, biased, one-sided, and absurd,' and began to believe Mr. Darcy's version. Then, she read the part about Austen and Denny, and found that Mr. Darcy was cold-blooded, but actually rational. Two hours later, she returned home to find that Mr. Darcy and Colonel Fitzwilliam had already arrived.

100.text: After finishing Mr. Darcy's letter, Elizabeth's mind was filled with questions. Initially, she was fascinated by Mr. Darcy's conservative views and his comments on Austen, believing his actions to be entirely influenced by his social status. However, as she continued reading Mr. Darcy's explanation of Wickham, her understanding became clearer. Soon, she realized that she knew almost nothing about Wickham. It wasn't until the evening, when Wickham's relationship with Darcy was revealed, that she began to reflect on why she had failed to notice his improper behavior. Through further reading and reflection, she discovered that her initial assumptions were 'blind, biased, one-sided, absurd,' and began to believe Darcy's version. Then, she read the part about Austen and Denny, and discovered that despite Darcy's seeming coldness, he was actually rational. Two hours later, when she returned home, she found that Mr. Darcy and Colonel Fitzwilliam were already there.

0.text: Cunegonde tells her story to Candide: Bulgar soldiers attack and kill her family and rape her. While Cunegonde fights off her attacker, a captain comes in and, enraged at the officer's disrespect, kills him. He then takes Cunegonde as a prisoner of war. The captain keeps Cunegonde as his servant for three months and then sells her to a Jewish businessman. The businessman shares her services with the same Inquisitor who ordered the execution of Pangloss and flogging of Candide. Cunegonde wards off the sexual advances of both men. Cunegonde attends the post-earthquake execution and recognizes Candide. Cunegonde's story ends. Back in the present, Candide and Cunegonde eat dinner together and hang out until one of her owners, the businessman Don Issachar, comes to get her.

2.text: Constanza de Rossi told Canidia her story: Bulgarian soldiers attacked and killed her family, and raped her. Although Constanza resisted the attackers, a military officer appeared, outraged by the officer's lack of decorum, and killed him. Then, he took Constanza as a captive. The officer kept Constanza as a servant for three months, and then sold her to a Jewish merchant. The merchant was the same one who ordered the killing of Pergolesi and the whipping of Canidia. Constanza successfully resisted the advances of both men. Constanza attended the trial following the earthquake and identified Canidia. Constanza's story came to an end. In reality, Canidia and Constanza dined together, chatting until their host, the Jewish merchant Donoy Isaac, came to take her away.

4.text:
Constance de Rossi told her story to Candide: Bulgarian soldiers attacked and killed her family, and raped her. Despite Constance resisting her attackers, a military officer appeared, outraged by the officer's impertinence, and killed him. Then, he took Constance away. 

The officer kept Constance as a slave for three months before selling her to a Jewish merchant. This merchant was the one who ordered the killing of Pereles and the flogging of Candide. Constance successfully resisted both of them. 

Constance appeared in court after an earthquake, and recognized Candide. Constance's story ended there. In fact, Candide and Constance ate together, talked until their master, the Jewish merchant Don Issac, came to take Constance away.

6.text:
Constancia de Ruiseor told Cathay her story: Bulgarian soldiers attacked and killed her family, and raped her. Although Constancia resisted her attackers, a soldier appeared, outraged by the soldier's indecent behavior, and killed him. Then, he took Constancia away.

This soldier kept Constancia as a slave for three months before selling her to a Jewish merchant. This merchant was the one who ordered the murder of Perels and the flogging of Cathay. Constancia successfully resisted them.

Constancia appeared in court after an earthquake, and identified Cathay. Constancia's story came to an end. In fact, Cathay and Constancia were having dinner together, talking until their owner, Jewish merchant Donoy Isaac, came to take Constancia away.

8.text:

The soldier held Constancia captive as a slave for three months before selling her to a Jewish merchant. That merchant was the one who ordered the murder of Perls and the flogging of Katherina. Constancia successfully resisted them.

Constancia appeared in court after an earthquake, recognizing Katherina. Constancia's story thus ended. In fact, Katherina and Constancia were dining together, discussing the topic, until their master, the Jewish merchant Dony Isaac, came to take Constancia away.

The soldiers kidnapped Constantia, keeping her as a slave for three months, then sold her to a Jewish merchant. This merchant was the one who ordered the killing of Pels and the whipping of Katrina. Constantia successfully resisted them.

Constantia appeared in court after the earthquake, identifying Katrina. Constantia's story ended like that. In fact, Katrina and Constantia were dining together, discussing the topic, until their owner, the Jewish merchant Dony Isaac, came to take Constantia away.

The soldiers kidnapped Constantia, tortured her for three months, and then sold her to a Jewish merchant. This merchant was the one who ordered the killing of Pearl and the flogging of Catherine. Constantia successfully resisted them.

Constantia appeared in court after an earthquake, recognizing Catherine. Constantia's story ended like that. In reality, Catherine and Constantia were having dinner together, discussing the topic until their master, Jewish merchant Doni Isaac, came and took Constantia away.

100.text:

Three months later, this soldier took away Constantin and sold him to a Jewish merchant. This merchant was the one who had ordered Peter's death and whipped Catherine. Constantin's actions infuriated his adversary.

Constantin appeared in court after the earthquake, recognized Catherine, marking the end of Constantin's story. In fact, Catherine and Constantin sat down to dinner together, discussing their conversation, until their master, the Jewish merchant Dino Isaac, appeared and took away Constantin.

0.text: Jane and Rochester have a quiet wedding three days after that. Diana and Mary are happy for her and say they will come to visit. St. John did not reply to the letter Jane sent to him regarding the wedding; however, he has since maintained a correspondence with her. Jane goes to see Adele and changes her school for a better and closer one. Jane then tells the reader that it has been ten years now that she has been married as she sits to write about her life. She and Rochester are always together, and after two years, he had regained sight in one of his eyes, enough to see his first-born son. Diana and Mary are both married and come to visit Jane, and she visits them. St. John went to India and is still there. He remained unmarried, and Jane relates that he feels that he will soon die and join God

2.text: After that, Jane and Rochester held a quiet wedding in three days. Diana and Mary were both extremely happy and said they would come to visit. St. John did not respond to Jane's letter about the wedding, but he continued to stay in touch with her. Jane went to visit Adle and moved Adle's school to a place closer to home in order to give her better education. Jane told the readers that it had been ten years since then, and she was now writing her life story. Jane and Rochester were together, and two years later, he regained enough vision in one eye to see their eldest son. Diana and Mary were both married and came to visit Jane, and Jane also went to visit them. St. John went to India and settled there. He remained unmarried, and Jane said she thought he believed he would soon meet God.
